text: <@U61NXB13P> Hi Alisha. I've just read your profile, hopefully I will be able to give you some good insights to help with your career plan. I'm just about to go into a day of meetings (in Algiers) but should have time this evening to chat. In the mean time, if you have any immediate questions, do let me know and I will get back to you later.

Good afternoon Christian, hope your meetings went well. I am currently studying English lit, History, Graphics& Psychology. I aspire to become a lawyer one day and heard you work in the legal profession. I have a list of Q's for you if you don't mind answering in your free time:
1. What does a typical working day look like for you?
2. Which university did you attend?
3. What is your role in the legal sector?
4. What's the best part of working in the legal sector? 
5. What's the hardest part of your job? 
(I also heard you love books, so what are some of your favourite books?) 
Hope to hear from you soon
Meetings went very well thank - a surprise meeting with the CEO of our client, but managed to prepare something for it quickly. To answer you questions, probably best if I start with number 3.

3. It's worth clarifying that I am not a lawyer. I work at a consultancy that provides expert witness services. I work closely with our clients (at the moment mainly large international energy companies) and with their legal teams in international disputes and arbitrations (basically court cases between companies). Basically, i work in international court cases providing evidence to the court and arguing why the evidence put forward by the other side is incorrect
that's the shortest description I think makes sense, but happy to clarify if needed

1. Typical working day - I work from home usually 2 days a week. When I go to the office, I generally get in at 7am and leave around 4pm if it isn;t too busy, with a short break from lunch. That is very different from how a lot of lawyers work, as they will generally get in later and stay late, especially junior lawyers who are worked pretty hard when cases are on

2. i was lucky, I had a very good maths teacher who pushed me to apply to Cambridge, which I didn't realise I could do. So I spent 4 years at Cambridge, but have also studied at University of London, which is excellent.

4. I work in the arbitration side of law, so my experience may be different from people who work in contract law, financial law etc. Personally, I love arguing and finding out the truth, and that is something I do every day in my job. I also love the pressure of arbitration - during the hearing itself (the end of a couple of years work, lasting a week or so) we will generally be working 16-18 hours a day, very intense intellectually, lots of think an challenging each others ideas and working out strategy for the rest of the hearing. That is incredibly rewarding, especially when surrounded by a team of very intelligent people

5. The hardest part of my job has been the travelling. I don;t do so much now, but for a few years I was abroad monday to friday almost every week. At first it's very glamorous, but eventually it gets very tedious. Unfortunately a lot of clients demand it, so it has to be done.

Books - yes, I do have a thing for books. Always a tough question to answer, as I read a very wide range - literature, sci-fi, history, philosophy, politics. The greatest book written is a tie between Lord of the Rings, The Count of Monte Christo, and Middlemarch (I wrote a dissertation on the philosophy of George Eliot, so am a big fan of her. Scenes of Clerical Life, her first book, is always worth a read). Other favourites are Somerset Maugham - "Painted Veil" and "On Human Bondage" are great examples of simple yet incredibly effective writing. I also love Russian literature, and finally finished War and Peace, which is incredible if the length doesn;t put you off. History - Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee is incredible - a revisionist take on American history, but important nonetheless. Books is something I could talk about all day, so I will stop there. What are your favourites?
That mini essay out of the way...

It sounds like you have a clear plan already - English and History then a law conversion course. That sounds like a great plan. Have you thought about what skills you will need as a lawyer, and how studying English and History will help develop those skills?
